questions.text: All of the following are indications of surgery in a patient of Potts' spine except?

choices.text: Progressive cauda equina syndrome/conus medullaris syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cold abscess without neurological complication

Explanation:

Cold abscess without neurological complication in a patient with Pott's spine can be managed conservatively with anti-tuberculosis medication.

  • Surgery is typically not indicated in such cases, as long as there are no neurological complications.

 

Surgical procedures:

  • Costo-transversectomy
  • Anterolateral decompression
  • HONGKONG procedure: Anterior decompression and spinal fusion
  • Laminectomy

 

Indications for surgery in patients without neurological complications

Indications for surgery in patients with neurological complications
  • Progressive bone destruction despite ATT
  • Failure to respond to conservative therapy
  • Paravertebral abscess when it has increased in size despite medical treatment
  • Spinal instability caused by destruction or collapse, destruction of two or more vertebrae, kyphosis
  • Prevention of severe kyphosis in young children with extensive dorsal lesions
  • Large paraspinal abscess
  • New or worsening neural complications or lack of improvement with conservative treatment
  • Paraplegia of rapid onset or severe paraplegia
  • Late-onset paraplegia
  • Neural arch disease
  • Painful paraplegia in elderly patients
  • Spinal tumor syndrome (epidural spinal tuberculoma without osseous involvement)

 

Middle path regimen in managing Pott’s spine:

Regimen:

  • Medical management in all patients + surgical management in the following situations:
  • Lack of response to chemotherapy
  • Recurrent disease
  • Severe neurological weakness
  • Static or progressive neuro deficit despite a course of ATT
  • Deformity
  • Debilitating pain
  • Instability

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is suffering from increasing difficulty in bending forward with stiffness of the spine and reduced chest movements. A CT was performed and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ankylosing spondylitis

Explanation:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the spine.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

 

  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

 

  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

 

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Milwaukee brace

Explanation:

  • The given image represents the Milwaukee brace.
  • The Milwaukee brace is used for structural scoliosis and fits snugly over the pelvis. It includes chin and head pads for active postural correction and a thoracic pad that presses on the ribs at the apex of the curve. While it is cumbersome, if well-made, it does not significantly interfere with activity. However, bracing is now used less frequently due to doubts about its effectiveness in altering the progression of scoliosis.

 

 

Boston brace (Option A): The Boston brace is used for low lumbar curves in scoliosis and does not include a head or chin component. It is a more streamlined brace that typically only covers the torso.

Taylor brace (Option C): The Taylor brace is used for spinal fractures or for patients recovering from spinal surgery. It provides support to the lumbar and lower thoracic spine but does not have the design elements (chin or head pads) seen in the Milwaukee brace.

ASHE brace (Option D): The ASHE (Anterior Spinal Hyperextension) brace is used to provide hyperextension support for the lumbar spine but is not used for scoliosis. It has a completely different structure compared to the Milwaukee brace.

questions.text: To which part of the vertebra are the screws fixed in spine fusion surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pedicle

Explanation:

  • In spine fusion surgery, screws are typically inserted into the pedicle of the vertebra. The pedicle is a bony structure that connects the vertebral body to the posterior elements (lamina and spinous processes), making it an ideal anchor point for screws. Pedicle screws provide strong fixation and allow for effective stabilization of the spine during fusion.

Incorrect Options:

Spinous process (Option A): The spinous process is the bony protrusion at the back of the vertebra, and it is not used for screw fixation in spine fusion surgery, as it does not provide enough stability.

Lamina (Option B): The lamina is part of the vertebra's posterior structure, but it is not the primary anchor point for screws in fusion surgery.

Facet joint (Option D): Facet joints are involved in the movement between vertebrae, but screws are not typically fixed into the facet joints for spine fusion.

questions.text: What is the method of scoliosis measurement portrayed in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cobb’s angle

Explanation:

  • The method of measurement of scoliosis given in the image is Cobb’s angle used to measure the degree of deviation and severity.

Management of Scoliosis: (depending on Cobb’s angle)

Cobb’s angle

Management

< 20°

Observation

20-60°

Bracing (Milwaukee brace)

>60°

Surgical management

Various angles in Orthopaedics:

Cobb angle (Option A)

Scoliosis

Bohler angle (Option B)

Calcaneum

Ferguson angle (Option C)

Kyphosis

Baumann angle (Option D)

Elbow fracture

Q angle

Patella

Kite angle

CTEV (Congenital talipus equino varus)

Southwick angle

SCFE (Slipped capital femoral epiphysis)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She was a non-restrained passenger in a car. She has pain in her neck and difficulty in neck movements. She has no associated neurological deficits. A neck collar is applied to protect the spinal cord. An X-ray of the neck is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hangman fracture

Explanation:

  • A Hangman fracture occurs due to hyperextension, often from high-impact trauma like a road traffic accident. It involves fractures of the C2 vertebra (axis), leading to anterior displacement. The injury is unstable, but neurological deficits are rare as the fracture can widen the spinal canal.

C2 Traumatic Spondylolisthesis (Hangman’s Fracture)

  • Cause: Traditionally from judicial hanging; now more commonly due to hyperextension injuries (e.g., force to the forehead, Forsyth mechanism).
  • Injury: Results in anterior translation at C2, leading to pars fractures and possible C2/3 disc disruption.
  • Neurological Injury: Uncommon, as the fractures can expand the spinal canal.
  • Stability Assessment: Depends on C2/3 disc status and facet integrity.

Levine & Edward Classification

Treatment

Type 1: Less than 3 mm subluxation, stable

Rigid cervical collar

Type 2: Greater than 4 mm subluxation, unstable

-Less than 5 mm - Reduction in axial traction and halo fixation for 6 to 12 weeks

-Greater than 5 mm - Require surgery

Type 2a: Unstable with flexion injury and angular deformity

Halo fixation

Type 3: Unstable with facet and anterior longitudinal ligament disruption

Require surgery

 

Jefferson's fracture (Option B): Involves a burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas), typically due to axial loading (e.g., diving accidents), not hyperextension.

Clay Shoveler's fracture (Option C): A fracture of the spinous process of C6, C7, or T1 due to sudden, forceful muscle contraction, not typically caused by hyperextension.

SCIWORA (Option D) (Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality): Refers to a spinal cord injury without visible fractures or dislocations on X-ray, often in young individuals with neck trauma, but it does not involve bone fractures.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with chronic lower back pain. A lateral lumbar spine X-ray is provided. Based on the radiological findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spondylolisthesis

Explanation: The image depicts slippage of vertebra over the other and most likely diagnosis is Spondylolisthesis.

 

Clinical Features of Different Types of Spondylolisthesis

Feature

Isthmic

Congenital

Degenerative

Symptoms
  • Asymptomatic or low back pain.
  • History of trauma in 50% of cases.
  • Common in both adults and children.
  • Pain in lower back, buttocks, legs, and toes.
  • Known as pseudospondylolisthesis.
  • Intermittent symptoms, especially in the elderly.
  • More common in women (5 times) and affects 4-10% of the population.
  • Pain in the back, buttock, or thigh.

Deformity
  • Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • Palpable step at L5–S1.(Step sign)
  • Short torso, protruding abdomen.
  • Transverse furrow at L5.
  • Vertical sacrum.
  • Flat buttocks and hamstring tightness.
  • Prominent L5 spinous process.
  • Scoliosis present in 13%.
  • Scoliosis and pelvic waddle.
  • Flat buttocks.
  • Stiffness of the spine; limited bending.
  • Stiffness of spine.

Neurological Issues
  • Rare involvement of L5 nerve root.
  • Involvement of L5 or S1 nerve root; L5 involvement is rare.
  • Neurological claudication.
  • Commonly affects L3–4.

 

 

Normal appearance

Spondylolysis

Spondylolisthesis
  • Resembles a Scottish dog
  • Collar Appearance: Indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis)
  • Defect without vertebral displacement
  • Separated Head and Neck
  • Defect with vertebral displacement

 

 

Spondylitis (Option A): Would show inflammatory changes (e.g., squaring of vertebral bodies, syndesmophytes in ankylosing spondylitis) rather than vertebral slippage.

Osteosarcoma (Option C): Primary malignant bone tumor, rare in spine, would present with destructive bony lesion and soft tissue mass, not a clean slip.

Vertebral fracture (Option D): Would show cortical disruption or collapse of vertebral body without smooth anterior translation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with chronic back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity. He also has a history of anterior uveitis. A lumbar spine X-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next investigation for early diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. MRI sacroiliac joints

Explanation:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy strongly associated with HLA-B27.
  • Early symptoms: Inflammatory back pain, morning stiffness, improvement with exercise, extra-articular features like anterior uveitis.
  • Radiological hallmark: Sacroiliitis — subchondral erosions, sclerosis, and eventual ankylosis
    • Initially, Subchondral Erosions develop at the lliac side of the Sacro-iliac Joints followed by Sclerosis & Proliferation
  • In early disease, plain X-rays may be normal because changes take years to appear.
  • MRI sacroiliac joints can detect bone marrow edema, synovitis, and erosions before they are visible on X-ray, enabling early diagnosis and treatment.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radioloxical Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae

 

  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

CT spine (Option A): CT is excellent for detecting bony detail and erosions, but it cannot detect active inflammation in early AS; changes may still be absent in the spine before sacroiliac involvement.

X-ray thoracolumbar spine (Option C): In early AS, spinal radiographs may be completely normal; sacroiliac joint involvement usually precedes spinal changes.

Bone scan (Option D): Bone scintigraphy can show increased uptake in inflamed areas, but it lacks the specificity and detailed anatomy provided by MRI, and it’s not the first-line choice for early AS detection.
